I AM A CHRISTIAN When I say..."I am a Christian" I'm not shouting "I'm clean livin'" I'm whispering "I was lost", Now I'm found and forgiven. When I say..."I am a Christian" I don't speak of this with pride. I'm confessing that I stumble And need CHRIST to be my guide. When I say..."I am a Christian" I'm not trying to be strong. I'm professing that I'm weak And need HIS strength to carry on. When I say..."I am a Christian" I'm not bragging of success. I'm admitting I have failed And need GOD to clean my mess. When I say..."I am a Christian" I'm not claiming to be perfect. My flaws are far too visible But GOD believes I am worth it. When I say..."I am a Christian" I still feel the sting of pain. Something Has Been Bothering Me... When I was off work in May because of my surgery, I became addicted to All My Children. So much so that I began taping it everyday after I went back to work. A couple of weeks ago they began to hint about the fact that Bianca was going to be raped. Then I saw Erica and Bianca on The View (my other addiction) and they confirmed what was going to happen, and also that Bianca was not going to report it. This really disturbed me! I knew that I wouldn't be able to watch it, but I couldn't figure out why. With me being so 'evolved' and having faced, conquered and become well acquainted with my dragons, I was surprised that I was so uncomfortable with the storyline. So I didn't tape AMC the day it all happened and really thought that I wouldn't watch the soap opera for a couple of months. I thought that I would get annoyed with Bianca for not telling. I lasted until that Friday :-). I tuned in just in time to see Bianca try to tell Erica about it, but change her mind. And yes, I was disturbed, but not for the reason that I'd expected. It made me extremely uncomfortable to recognize that I would have done exactly what Bianca did...stay quiet. And for the same reasons that she did. It's been bothering me because it took me so many years to talk about my childhood (and start getting help 11 years ago), and I can still find reasons to try to deal with things, especially the big ones, by myself. My best friend, Dana, says that it's like pulling teeth to get information out of me when there's something wrong. She's right...it's easier for me to talk about what's bothering me when I've figured out the cause and/or the solution. I know this is a residual from not talking for so many years, but I can't seem to shake this one; it even took me days to write about this. AMC's storyline has added to my list of things to work on this year.

When Facts Are Fiction One of the biggest mistakes that people make in relationships is believing that they "know" someone just because they know some "things" about them. Whether it be your relationship with family, friends or God, having facts without substance adds up to fiction, and leads to friction and miscommunications. The substance comes from spending time with someone and really being there, and not mentally or emotionally someplace else. One of my favorite lines from a movie is from "Nell"; Jodie Foster says that we (people) never look at each other, and that we never look each other in the eyes. My thought is that the way into someones heart may vary, but the way to see into their heart and soul is through their eyes. Most people aren't consciously aware of this, but subconsciously, that's why they look away. Another mistake that people make is to think that they know someone based on facts received through a mutual acquaintance, friend or family member. What we seem to not realize is that the information shared about someone is altered by our interpretation as well as the interpretations of the person receiving the "facts". Which will make the "facts" fiction. So what we end up with is a whole lot of folks walking around thinking we "know" people, when nobody "knows" anybody. And the worst part of it all is no one is asking questions because everyone thinks they already "know" the answers. Just Another Thought!

Misery Loves Comfort Everyone says that "misery loves company". I say that misery loves comfort even more. Have you ever noticed that when you feel like crap, you don't mind looking like crap? I don't get overly dressed for a funeral because I figure if I'm going to feel miserable, I may as well do it in comfort. It's even better when you're miserable and you don't have to leave home. You put on your worst sweats (the ones you should have thrown away five years ago), and you don't comb your hair or shower for a couple of days. You really only want to see other people who are miserable, if they look as jacked up as you do. Don't let someone come over "claiming" to be in misery, but looking like they just walked off the cover of a magazine. They're just fronting and claiming misery to make you feel better. Yeah Right...Get Outta Here With That! Like I said, misery loves comfort more than company.

Just A Thought Back in the day when my friends would get annoyed and say that I was opinionated, I would deny it. I have since learned to embrace it, and accept the fact that I do have an opinion about most subjects. I am actually multi-opinioned! So recently when someone would ask me what I think about the war, at first (before it actually began) I would give an opinion, but then it became moot. Not because they said that we were winning the war. But because I suddenly had a different view of what the "big picture" might be. I had a thought... The U.S. is focusing on the wrong enemy...Sadaam, Osama, North Korea are not where we should be focusing our fear. We should be worried about the fact that whatever the feeling was in this country that prompted the fore-fathers to put "In God We Trust" on the currency has dissipated. I recently read an e-mail expressing concern about the movement to take "under God" out of the pledge of allegience and "in God we trust" off of the currency. I couldn't help but wonder why people were so shocked about the possibility of these things happening, when it is the obvious next step. I'll explain... The e-mail also stated that statistics show that 84% of Americans believe in God. My question is how many of us "believers" wake up every morning and say to ourselves, "Today I'm going to do something to please God? or what am I not going to do?" How many of us "believers" are actually serving Him in some capacity? I am not a religious fanatic...Hell, most days I suck at being a Christian. But in my attempt to read the bible in a year, I can't help but notice what happens to God's people when they turn their backs on Him. Who can turn on a television, radio or read a newspaper, and still give a valid and convincing argument that the U.S. has not done just that. And we've done it in the worst way possible...by selling the souls of our children to the devil. Everywhere they look they're being encouraged to smoke, drink and have sex (with anyone they want!). It's easier for them to get their hands on drugs and guns than it is to get a good and safe education. Because I work with kids, it's hard for me to ignore the fact that our education system is a joke. There truly is no effort to educate all kids equally. If you ask an average middle school kid in a low income community to define flabergasted, he/she would probably say that it's a fat person who farted. I wont try to give a solution to this problem, but I will leave you with this... On his website, www.infinitekarma.com, my friend Wallace asks this question: "If people have karma, do nations have karma? If so, what will we do when this nation's chickens come home to roost?"

When does WANT began to look like NEED? Can you tell the difference between them? I was talking to a friend recently about the difference between needing people in our lives and wanting them. And then I had two separate conversations about this yesterday. Apparently I've given others the impression that I NEED to have my brother live with me. It's funny that events have occurred to bring up this conversation that's been going on in my head for a few weeks. I know that I've given him that impression also, and it has not been good for him. His lack of motivation and his complacency have been enabled by the thought that I need him. I'll admit that I've been spoiled by him living here; he goes to the store when I don't feel like doing it, cares for the lawn, cleans the kitchen, washes my car and things along that nature. I knew that we had a problem when he claimed that I would never cut the branches on the bushes growing outside of his room and my office. He really believed it! So now things have blown up at work and I let him know that he must either find a new place to work or a new place to live, because we can't have both. He doesn't like the job enough to treat it or me (as his immediate supervisor) with any respect. I'm slightly amused by the conversation of want or need because I have considered myself 'emotionally autistic' for a long time. I coined the phrase to describe how I feel when I'm really going through something. Those times when my best friend says that it's really hard to get through to me. I know that I shut everything down and everyone out; I don't feel much of anything. We laugh because I say that it's a good thing that she 'knows' that I love her, because I don't 'feel' a thing. After I'm done dealing with whatever took me there, it takes a while to get the wall completely down. So I've been trying to work on this and rely on others to help me get through things. It's gotta be faster and easier :-). But I haven't been doing a good job of turning this around because it's a 'want', not a 'need'. Funny huh?

GFG's...Gifts From God People come and go from our lives often, and we may never why. But it's a very interesting feeling to meet someone and "know" that they are suppose to be in your life. A knowledge that creates a sense of urgency and panic at the thought of never seeing them again. The two instances of this phenomenon that stand out most for me happened five years and again a year ago. Five years ago I was having a conversation with a volunteer at the BGC of Pomona (okay!...it was community service), and among other things she was talking about moving to Arizona. That's when the panic happened. So I invited her to a party that I was having at the end of the week, and I was very adamant about her saying yes. She is now my best friend and we laugh at how she thought it was wierd that I was so persistant. (She actually thought I was weird but she couldn't resist my charm). She admits that because she was shy and guarded, if I hadn't pursued the friendship it would have never become what it is today. Last year it happend again. I saw this woman and I would have bet money that we'd me before. My friends and I eventually began a conversation with her and her husband, and we couldn't figure out where we could have met. But still there was a comfort that wasn't only a result of the Mai Tai's. And again I had that feeling that when we all parted that day, it couldn't end there. So once again I listened to the voice that was saying, "Don't let go, this is going somewhere I promise". She and I are friends now but we haven't talked about this, and she also must think that it's a little odd that I've put so much effort into making this happen. That's okay though :-)! I listened to the voice five years ago and now I've been blessed with three kids, a husband and a wife (inside joke). And so far I've gotten four friends out of last summers encounter. So all I can say is never look a gift-God in the mouth.

Intoxicated Concentration is an Oxymoron! Four years ago I quit drinking. I started drinking again last summer at the beginning of my vacation. This summer I'm quitting again, at the end of my vacation, for a few reasons. One reason is the many goals that I've set for myself this year...starting the company, writing the book and just focusing on getting on and staying on the path that God has set for me. It's all about "heading in the right direction" and being able to "hear" what God is trying to tell me at all times. What good is it for God to have this great plan if I don't know what it is. And He's not holding back His plan for me, I haven't been listening. But lately some things have been coming in loud and clear, but it seems so big that my fear keeps trying to tone it down or drown out what I'm hearing. So I'm going to quit drinking and concentrate. Because my biggest challenge is living up to my own potential. Another reason for the 'brain cell retention program' is that aging is slowing down my memory enough without me helping to speed up the process.

So Much For Not Wanting Kids!!... Last week I had a real parental attack. Mayah, my 3 year old God-daughter/niece (and road-dog) was at the Boys & Girls Club with me as she is everyday. Suddenly she was choking and I couldn't figure out on what. She said that she didn't put anything in her mouth, but I wasn't sure. When she turned red and coughed up some blood, I grabbed her and rushed her to emergency. The whole way to the hospital, she was screaming. I had a few seconds of panic, but remained outwardly calm through it all. My calm almost came to an end as she spoke to her mom on the phone and began to calm down herself. We were at the hospital and with a nurse and I started to tear up as Mayah talked to Dana on the phone and told her what happened. She was so cute! I lost it even more later...Not because during it I thought she would die or anything. But remembering the look in her eyes when she was so scared and in pain. I now understand the parental feeling of helplessness that comes from not being able to help your kid.

My sisters and I worked on the obituary... Sharon Ann Gilmore was the youngest of three children born to Otis and Annie Holmes on November13,1946. Early in life she faced challenges that she refused to be defeated by. The strength gained in her early years would later provide the foundation necessary to weather her recent storms. Sharon was a very generous woman. She opened her home to whoever needed a hot meal and a warm bed. She never turned away anyone who needed a place to stay even if it meant sacrificing her own comfort, or the comfort of her children. She loved to cook and she did it well. A couple of her signature dishes were her peach cobbler and potato salad. Family and friends would put in requests to have their favorite dish made for special gatherings and she was always willing to oblige. When asked about her greatest accomplishment, she replied, “my children”. Sharon gave birth to five children, all different, yet all spoiled. While making sacrifices for family and friends seemed to come naturally to her, the lengths to which she would go without became more evident when it came to the needs of her children. She never claimed to be a perfect mother and was fully aware of her mistakes, but she gave all of who she was and what she had to her children. Sharon leaves in her children Angela Louise, Charlene Marie, Lavinia Ann, Charles Louis, and LaJuan Otis her mark on the world. De’Andre, Aaryon, Alexandria and Reginae were their Nanna’s pride and joy. Her sisters Darlene Coleman-Rogers and Ernestine Coleman are her only surviving siblings.

We All Have An Ark To Build "Everybody's got a thing..." Stevie Wonder God has given us all something specific to do. Sometimes it takes years to figure out what that thing is. It may take a while because we're not listening, or we have to go through some things before He get's us where we need to be, to be able to hear Him. Whatever the reason, there comes a time when some of us find it hard to ignore what we've been asked to do. How do we know when it's time to build our ark? Here are a few signs... 1. We don't want to do it...we think we can't because it's too big or we've never done anything like it before. All kinds of reasons come up. 2. No one else thinks we can do it...They might even think we're crazy for thinking it. 3. There is a persistant nagging in your gut. No matter how much we try to put it out of our minds, we can't get comfortable in our own skin, and nothing makes us as happy as we know we can be. One of the things that stands out for me when I watch Joan of Arcadia (one of my new favorite tv shows--Friday nights), is that God stops her from telling anyone that He talks to her. My theory on this (other than that's how they write it) is that it is not because He knows that people will think she's crazy. It's because some people will believe her. What happens after that is she begins to share with someone what her assignments are and they give their input on how she should handle it. This takes away form her coming up with the answers by just walking by Faith and calling on God when she runs into a wall. She would feel that she has someone to talk to other than God...who is really all she needs. A few months ago, I began having a recurring dream. These dream showed me my ark. And it was frightening!! Was It Expected? That's the question that I get from people who didn't know about my mother's medical history. It's an equally valid and invalid question. Even though we knew any surgery would be complicated, and I even predicted the day that she would die, the answer to the question is Hell No! No matter how old you are or sick she is, you never expect and are never really prepared for your mother to be gone. Her doctor told us last June that all of the arteries in her heart were blocked, except for one which had a little space for blood to pass through. That was almost a year ago, and she's been through a lot since, but she kept bouncing back. She spoiled us so much that even though I'd pray (when she was in a lot of pain) that God would relieve her of the pain, even if that meant taking her. In the next breath I'd think, "I take that back, make her better because I'm not ready yet." So it was a shock when my cousin called to tell me that she died. It was not expected.

Good & Terrible If you saw the movie 'Coming To America' as many times as I have, you will remember when the group Sexual Chocolate was singing and the old man said, "That boy's good". And the other one said, "Good and Terrible". (If you didn't see it, it was funny). Everyone keeps asking me how I'm doing, and that's my answer...good and terrible. It looks like I'm doing good, and most of the time I am, but...I'm not dealing with this well. Actually, I'm not dealing with it at all. Everytime the thought enters my head that I can't call my mother, I change the channel. I completely shut down and I can't feel anything. I even avoid looking at pictures. Tuesday night my sisters and brothers and I went to my mother's house to go through her things. We all did well..we ate pizza and watched American Idol as we decided who was taking what. I took a jewelry/music box and a couple of other things. And they are all still in the trunk of my car. At this point, I've held it back for so long that I'm just scared of the pain that comes with truly facing it all. Having both of my sisters go into the hospital in the last two weeks has not helped.

Thanks... To everyone who called, e-mailed, sent cards, flowers, plants and money. It has helped a lot just knowing that you care. For those who attended the funeral...I am forever greatful. My reason for letting so many people know about my mother's death was not to get you to come to the funeral. I've mentioned before that Dana says I have a hard time allowing people to be there for me; so I didn't want to deny anyone that opportunity. And also, I expect to hear from all of you if something tragic or great happens in your lives.

Extreme Makeovers I've decided that I want to be white. I want a law that says that I can legally put on any document that asks for my race, that I am white. I don't want to chance anything else about me; I will remain ghetto-fabulous, strainght outta Compton (Tarbabe 4 Life). But I want all of the advantages that come with being white. Written or not, we all know what those advantages are. I know that some will argue, "how can you claim to be white and it's obvious by looking at you that you are not"? I looked up Webster's definition of 'white', in regards to race, I know that I don't fit the description, so I want the definition changed so that I can have the right to claim that I am white. It's not like God said "okay, I'm going to call these people black, those mexican, some asian and some white. Unlike marriage , it's a man-made defintion so there shouldn't be a problem making the change.

Dion Fontenot People keep asking me why I no longer enjoyed working at the Boys&Girls Club, so instead of giving everyone the long answer, I say that it was time to move on. They still don't get why I would rather be unemployed than have a steady, sufficient income. So I tell some of them about Dion. Last summer I had my best group of L.I.T.'s (Leaders In Training-a program at the B&GC), and Dion was one of them. He had just graduated from High school and came in looking for a job. I told him that we weren't hiring at the moment. He asked what he could do to get some training so that he would be prepared when we started hiring. I was impressed, so I included him in the L.I.T. program. From mid-June thru the end of August this group of kids worked their butts off. They were only required to put in 2 hours per day, but they came in around noon and worked unitl 5 or 6pm almost everyday. They never gave me a problem or complained about doing anything that I asked of them. I told them about the trip to Lake Tahoe that was scheduled for the end of summer and paid for through the L.I.T. grant for the participants to attend. They were excited! But when it came time to pick the members to attend the trip, it was decided that previous L.I.T. participants would attend instead of the current group. Even when they were having trouble getting enough members who 'could' go, they didn't invite the current ones. I was embarassed and felt bad for them because I knew that it was because of their attachment to me. I had already been told that I wasn't going, and I was the program director. Dion and Randy had to witness other staff members going around the club asking kids who had never participated in the program, to call home to see if they could go on the trip. In the end, they filled two spots with the two current L.I.T.'s who had put in the least amount of hours, because they had been members of the club longer. They had completed 50 to 60 fewer hours than the others. I was HOT!!! Fade to November... I asked if the summer L.I.T.'s could be included in the outing to Magic Mountain to participate in the annual Christmas toy drive in December. I was told that they could only go if they came to the Thanksgiving dinner at the Club to help serve the meal. I was fuming!!! They now were required to come work some more, so that they could work some more (at the toy drive) in order to get the priviledge of going into Magic Mountain for a few hours after they were done working. At this point I'm so pissed that my ulcer is bothering me. But I decide to call them all and give them the choice. No one was home for the first two calls. Then I got to Dion... His sister answered the phone and when I asked for Dion she told me that he had died in October. I was devastated! She told me that he'd had Krohn's Disease (an intestinal disorder). After I hung up the phone it took everything I had not to start vomitting and/or crying (I was at work alone with the kids on a Saturday). I sat there thinking how those kids had given us their whole summer and Dion had given us the rest of his life. He knew but never told us that he was sick. I kept hearing him say "I can't wait to go to Lake Tahoe", because the trip was the week before his 19th birthday. Instead he died one month after his birthday. And now the club wanted them to come and give more. That was the day that I knew that I had to get away from there.

I Hate Reality TV First of all it isn't real! People who know that they are being watched are going to act a certain way. They like to say that they forget about the cameras...yeah right! I get enough reality from some of my favorite shows like all of the Law and Orders and CSI (Las Vegas). I've not been a huge sci-fi fan (some exceptions), but at least it requires some imagination. They put on a great tribute which I really enjoyed and it stirred in me a sense of pride at the fact that we started something that's still going strong. They say that rap music lives because it reflects the realities of life for our black culture. Okay...but we've been talking about that now for the past 25 years. When do we switch the conversation (lyrics) to what could and should be instead. I must say that I agree with everything that Dr. Bill Cosby has to say about how inadequately we are raising our kids. And I'd like to add that like Moses did for the Jews, Martin Luther King showed us the promise land. But since his death, we've chosen to stay in the wilderness. We must change our perception of slavery and take into consideration that God allowed us to be brought over here because this is where He wanted us. In four years we will have completed our 40 year stint in the wilderness. Are we going to stay there are start living up to our God-given potiential? ckingme17@aol.com

Must Be On The Right Road Saturday I flew back from Florida where I went for the wedding of one of my best friends. Up until about 12 years ago you would have never gotten me on an airplaine. I admit that my control issues extend to my need to have my feet somewhere near the ground and steady. This is also the reason that I don't swim. I credit my stronger relationship with God as the reason that I don't panic at the thought of being up that high. I even ask for a seat next to the window. On the the flight from Houston there was probably an hour and a half of turbulance in the 3 hour trip to LAX. I was amazed at how calm I felt. I just kept thinking, "God has a plan for me, and I'm just getting started so I'm not going to die today". I arrived safely at LAX and was picked up by my best friend. (She's going to kill me for saying this...) Her driving scares the hell out of me! She drives very fast even when she's doing those distracting things that we all do. Plus she moves in and out of lanes. During the drive I closed my eyes alot or turned towards her to talk and not look where we were going. I wasn't so sure that I was going to live anymore. I thought, "I'm too late, maybe I took to long to listen to what God wanted me to do". I shook that off and thought that maybe we would just be in an accident. But guess what! We got pulled over by a CHP officer. I was so busy trying not to look at anything but her that I never saw him. I was worried that we got stopped because that's a terrible feeling. He gave her a break and didn't give her a ticket for speeding, just for window tinting. The rest of the ride was done close to the speed limit. It didn't hit me until today that getting pulled over was God looking out for us. So I feel like I must be Headed In The Right Direction! ckingme17@aol.com

And then I spotted it out of the side of my eye, coming at me. It was a pretty big misquito! I panicked, lifted my elbow to keep it from flying directly at my face. But in the meantime, the telephone that I was holding in my hand nailed me in the mouth. I busted my lips...yeah lips, in the plural! The right side of my top and bottom lips were swollen and the bottom one was bleeding pretty good. In my pain the only thing I could think of was when are they going to spray on my street! ckingme17@aol.com
